One interesting place where this shows up is the gender pay gap. While it is TRUE that on average, women make less than men, if you dig in, you find that within any given field, women actually make MORE than men on average. The difference between them really is what jobs each gender goes for, and paints a different story from just discrimination against women, instead showing that for one reason or another, men tend to take jobs with higher pay, typically because they are more dangerous or are manual labor.
This makes the pay gap a much more complicated question. For example, is this distinction one that even warrants change or even if men within the affected job fields are being short changed? Should we encourage women to take more labor intensive jobs to even out the work force, or does incentivizing this inherently undercut the purpose of equality?

so like, going back to the first example
100% (1/1) (0) of cats with treatment survive and 25% (1/4) (0.25) of humans survive w/ treatment, whereas 75% (3/4) (0.75) of cats w/o treatment survive, and 0% (0/1) (0) of humans w/o treatment survive
averaging the humans and cats with treatment, how the video does it is like saying the average of 1/1 and 1/4 is (1+1)/(4+1), coming to 2/5, aka 40%
but that’s just not how you average fractions (you need to add the denominators when they are the same)
doing it how you would normally average fractions would give (4+1)/(4+4), or even (1.0+0.25)/(1+1)
both of which come to 5/8, aka 62.5%

doing the same process with the untreated humans and cats give:
(incorrect) avg of 3/4 and 0/1 is (3+0)/(4+1) = 3/5 (60%)
(correct) avg of 3/4 (aka 0.75) and 0/1 (aka 0 or 0/4) would make (3+0)/(4+4) or (0.75+0)/(1+1), both coming to 3/8, aka 37.5%

note: the process of averaging a fraction like 0.75/1 (same as 3/4 and 0.75) and 0/1 (same as 0/1 and 0) would be the same as (1/2) * (0.75+0)
aka, half of the two numbers added together, which is the same as (numA+numB)/(1+1)
(just in case you haven’t got it yet)

The percentage is not an amount, but a ratio of the full amount. That means you can't just add 2 percentages together if they each represent a portion of different full amounts. For example, I have 2 boxes of jelly beans. Box A contains 10 while Box B contains 1000. 10% of Box A is a single bean while 10% of Box B is 100 beans. You can't just add them together to 101 beans and call it 10% + 10%=20%. 101 beans is not 20% of 10 + 1000 = 1010 beans. 20% of 1010 is actually 202.

The only way to logically do the math you want to do is to make the total number of cats and the total number of humans equal. This means you can't have 1 cat representing 100% and 1 person only representing 25%. If 1 green tick = 25%, then 100% must be 4 green ticks. This makes the tally 5 green vs 3 red = average of 62.5% chance of survival under treatment between cats and humans; 3 green vs 5 red = average of 37.5% chance of survival without treatment between cats and humans.

If that's still hard to wrap your head around, just swap the two for men and women. Given that the population of men and women are identical, 100% women + 25% men surviving under treatment (100 + 25) / 2 = 62.5% of the global population surviving. VS only 75% women survive and all men die, that is (75 + 0) / 2 = 37.5% global population surviving without treatment. DUH it's so clear!

So this really isn't a paradox, it's just you getting confused and being terrible at maths.

There are a LOT of people in the comments that either can't listen or don't understand what is being said.  This paradox arises out of how sample spaces work.  That's the entire point guys.  You can't look at percentages without considering the sample space it comes from.  And you can't say "well, just have equal sample spaces" because that is functionally impossible.  You are never going to get the exact same amount in all four cases in every situation.  Real world limitations FORCE unequal samples on you, and the entire point of this paradox is that you need to be wary of how that will influence your purely statistical conclusions.

I just realized: Simpson's paradox is only a paradox if you are INCREDIBLY disingenuous with your data points.
The cat/pill square only has one green checkmark; it should have four green checkmarks.
At 0:50, it shouldn't be 40%/60% on the right side of the screen. It should be 66%/33%

Before watching the rest of the video, this is a mathematical trick. You can't just add the ticks and crosses together because they represent fractions with different denominators. 1 out of 1 cats is 100%, for example. What you need to do is either sum the PERCENTAGES (not ticks and crosses) of survivors or take their mean average. For treated cats/people, that's a sum of 125% and a mean of 62.5% For untreated cats/people, that's a sum of 75% or a mean of 37.5%. Since that's about the opposite of what minutephysics said, that creates an opportunity for them to tell me that I made a mistake. But, if you're smart enough, you can look over the calculations yourself instead of stupidly basing your belief on the appeal to authority logical fallacy. There was a meta-study done regarding health and pollution from vehicle exhausts. The researchers started out with the proposition that the closer a person lives to a road, the greater their exposure to polluted air. This seems to be a reasonable idea on the face of it. They tabulated a population of people and discovered a strong correlation between the distance a person's front door is from a main road with life expectancy. Those who lived further from the road lived significantly longer. The researchers concluded that this was compelling evidence that living near the pollution from traffic on a main road has significant negative health effects. Although their conclusion may well be correct, the evidence they collected did not support it.

It turned out that they had ignored a significant secondary indicator of life expectancy which was also strongly correlated with the distance of a person's residence from a road. People who have larger incomes tend to have healthier lifestyles and healthcare. They also tend to live in bigger houses that are set back further from the road.

Less than 1 minute into this video, I already see the problem. Improper weighting. For example, in the treated section, the "one" cat that is needed to illustrate 100% could be 1 cat or possible 1000 cats. If it's 1000 cats, but still only 4 people (or 8 or 12 or 16), the successfully treated portion is gonna be ~99%.  The treated group assumes 80% of those that got treatment were humans (which may or may not be true), but that only 20% of those that didn't get treatment were humans.  If this were the case, you have two very dissimilar groups, indicating a very poor study design.

В демонстрации парадокса Симсона (на 21-ой секунде видео, https://youtu.be/ebEkn-BiW5k?t=21 ) допущена очень серьезная логическая ошибка-подмена - утрата весовых коэффициентов слагаемых.

Если бы даже они взяли среднее:
С таблеткой: 100% + 25% = 125% / 2 = 63%
Без таблетки: 75% + 0% = 75% / 2 = 33%
И то бы мы увидели логичные результаты - с таблеткой лучше, чем без таблетки, которые видели ранее.

А еще бы былее правильно было взять соразмерные величины:
С таблеткой: 100% - это не 1 здоровый кот, а 4 из 4
Без таблетки: 100% - это не 1 мертвый человек, а 4 из 4
соразмерные величины можно слагать:
С таблеткой: 4 (кота) + 1 (человек) = 5 / 8
Без таблетки: 3 (кота) + 0 (человек) = 3 / 8

Снова же - никакого парадокса не вижу: 5 / 8 > 3 / 8, т.е. применяемое лекарство более полезно, чем вредно. Те же данные, что получались и в начальном эксперименте.

There’s a flaw with that logic. If 100% of all cats survive and 25% of all humans survive, I can conclude our test sample will have 4 cats, and 4 humans/some multiple of 4. The same thing goes for the zero, so it should be represented as ❎❎❎❎ instead of just one ❎. I haven’t watched the whole video, but I’m assuming that, someone somewhere has realized this and the people who made this video utilized this discovery as they explained this statistical phenomenon. If there was just one human, and one cat tested, for the experiment where 100% of cats survived, and 0% of humans survived then the data would change. 12.5% would be the top percentage, and 32.5% would be the bottom percent. I’m that case, this analysis would be correct, but I’m deducing that the 100% cats that survived, wouldn’t just account for one cat, likewise to whereas 0% of humans that survived, wouldn’t just account for one human.

The initial comparison conflates absolute numbers with representative percentages. You've used two ticks and three crosses to represent 40%, whereas you've used three ticks and two crosses to represent 60%. The thing is, the ticks and crosses you're using to draw the those conclusions represent different values.

The tick assigned to the cat which takes the pill represents 100%. A single tick assigned to the cat that does not take the pill is equal to 25%. A similar thing is done with the humans. Three ticks representing 25% each hold more weight than one tick representing 100% in the supposed paradox, which is a conclusion reached because three is more than one. What's ignored here is that the 'three' represent three lots of 25%, whereas the 'one' represents one group of 100%. The ticks mean completely different things, so the comparison is completely erroneous.

this isn't actually a paradox at all. It's merely an artefact of poor standardisation of data.
Each datapoint has to be standardised according to its "class" or "type". You can't apply the standardisation of pears to apples, so to speak. And it should go without saying that randomly combining or fusing standardisation techniques is a bad idea too.



Interestingly enough, Netflix, Amazon and any other company that allows users to "rate" products already use techniques to circumvent this "problem". When giving an "average" rating to a product, what is used is not a simple arithmetic mean. The average is standardised over many different classes/types of users (e.g. users that always give high ratings, vs users that always give low ratings, etc...). Similarly, when recommending a product to the user, the rating is averaged with regard to the product's class. For example, if a user likes mystery movies, a moviee will be recommended to them based on how that movie compares to other mystery movies, not on how it compares to, say action movies, etc....
Such methods are so common and so vital to modern data analysis, that monetary prizes counting up to 6 digits are be handed out to people, who can come up with more precise and/or efficient ways to do these calculations.

The "cat/human disease" example was poorly done, and actually a good example of torturing data to reach a prescribed conclusion.
Or, just sloppily constructing a demonstration that does not demonstrate what you intended it to.
You compare one of one group, to four of the other group in both scenarios (receives treatment or doesn't receive treatment) in order to frame the comparisons in percentages.
I get that, but, then, you take it over to the side and frame the comparisons in individual quantities - that's apples and oranges stuff.

The only correct way to do this is have four cats and four humans in EACH box so that, in the treated category, a 100% survival rate in one group can be quantitatively compared with a 25% survival rate in the other.
In this way, it would show four cats and one human out of eight sample size, survive; or a 62.5% survival rate.
In the untreated category, there are only three survivors out of the eight sample size (all cats, no humans); or a 37.5% survival rate.

Looked at from the perspective of the individuals, whether cat or human, if I'm a cat, I have a 100% chance of living if I take the treatment and a 25% chance of dying if I don't - I'm taking the pill.
If I'm a human, I have a 100% chance of dying if I don't take the treatment, and a 25% chance of living if I do - I'm taking the pill.
You REALLY have to torture the numbers to come up with the claptrap conclusions you put in there to the contrary.

When you normalize sample size and don't switch between skewed quantities to simplify percentages, either way you slice it, it comes up peanuts - there is no interpretation that shows non-treatment is better than treatment.

In the first half of the "Paradox Part 2" video, the narrator argues that Simpson's Paradox can account for much of the so-called bias that we can see in university admissions (i.e., it might appear that universities are admitting a greater percentage of men applicants than women applicants, but Simpson's Paradox shows us that when we break down the applicants by major degree, the bias almost disappears entirely. This is because women are far more likely to apply for humanities and social science degrees than STEM degrees). In the second half of the video, the narrator proceeds to argue (without presenting any evidence), that it's not the universities that are biased, but rather the entire world that is biased (this effectively deprives women of agency. He implicitly suggests that women who, by their own volition, choose lower-paying humanities degrees are being subconsciously "shunted" to these lower-paying degrees, thus are making choices against their better interests). Towards the end of the video, he throws in a line about "equal pay for equal work," even though his OWN method of statistical analysis shows that the the "women earn 70 cents on the dollar" narrative is based in faulty reasoning, because it doesn't account for the fact that many women choose lines of work that pay less (and many women choose to take time off from work to have children). Women and men have equality of opportunity. A greater proportion of men choose STEM careers that pay more. A greater number of women choose "caring" professions like teaching and social work, careers that pay less. Unfortunately, he doesn't really answer (or even ask) the question of WHY women are more likely to choose these careers, he simply attributes this choice to some sort of internalized oppression.

I do care about equality of opportunity. You don't measure it by the proportion of the outcome.
You also don't measure it by the amount of people in a group who go into a certain field.

When you have two fundamentally different groups (men and women) you cannot in any way expect the proportions to reflect one another. That's because men and women, overall, are different, have different interests and personalities, and will make different choices. Obviously I'm not saying ALL men are this way and ALL women are that way, but overall, there is a difference.

Even if you want to call it a societal problem, then we fundamentally disagree, and you're no longer advocating for equality of opportunity.
It doesn't matter to me if people are stimulated to make one choice or another. At the end of the day the path you take is your own choice and nobody can take that away from you.
Besides, you can hardly say women are shunted towards more crowded, less productive careers with the amount of "get women into stem!" projects. Now, personally, I take absolutely no issue with these programs. Why? Because I don't care if people want to stimulate other people to make certain choices. There's no issue unless there's force or threats involved (e.g. parents telling their daughter/son they will no longer financially support them if they go into X career)

Rather than trying to socially engineer society to reflect the desired proportion of women somewhere, how about we face the fact that individuals are entitled to their own decisions, and there's nothing wrong with whatever they choose? Point to the actual discrimination, rather than clutching at straws and saying "you can't conclude there is no bias anywhere else in education". The null hypothesis shouldn't be "there is bias against women". Your default position shouldn't be that either, regardless of historical oppression (which, btw, is often way overstated) and whatnot.

Right now, there's actually a measurable bias against men coming out of college. Women are more likely to get hired after they get their degree in STEM.
That's an example of something I do worry about, actual discrimination. I don't care if that discrimination is in favor of one group or the other. But I'm tired of hearing that women are oppressed with a poor basis to back it up.

Another real life example is the Berkley lawsuit in the '70s.  The overall acceptance rate of male applicants was much higher than for female applicants, so they were accused of being biased against females.  When they looked at individual departments to see which one was discriminating against females, they found that each department was accepting females at higher rates then males.  The paradox was caused by most males applying to departments with high acceptance rates while most females were applying to ultra-competitive departments with low acceptance rates.  e.g. 25 females applied to a department with a 68% acceptance rate, while 341 applied to a department with a 7% acceptance rate.

Overall, I enjoyed the video and as an aspiring data scientist I find this paradox to be quite a great takeaway and reinforcement on maintaining that correlation doesn't prove causation.

However, I would like to state that there's a mathematical issue in creating the statistics earlier on I wanted to address. The percentages of 40% and 60% aren't based on equal weights so the logic is flawed. Assigning equal value to the percentages should be based upon the weights being the same. In this instance, there's 1 mark in one grid and 4 in another. However, the aggregated percentage is then equivocated to the total marks, which is in essence comparing apples to oranges (if you will) rather than apples to apples. The proper weighting would have 4 marks per grid to ensure equivalence.

If the percentages are held in equal weight, the above percentage would be 125 / 2 = 62.5 ( % ) and the bottom percentage would be 75 / 2 = 37.5. ( % ).

Another way this can be demonstrated is with the first row consisting of 5 green checks and 3 red X's for the pill ( 62.50% ) and the bottom row consisting of 3 green checks and 5 red X's for without the pill ( 37.50% .)

I hope this message doesn't fall on deaf ears and this oversight is reviewed and corrected (if my analysis isn't flawed.) Aside from that, I'd like to say thanks for sharing this paradox demonstrating our inclination of bias as it's an interesting concept I've not encountered. I've enjoyed your videos and look forward to more in the future!

I'm not sure about connections between race and IQ as the arguments seem biased and based on too much speculation or manipulation for either outcome. So not going there.
I'm guessing there is little genetic difference when it comes to intelligence. Not saying there is none, after all human populations have been separated for thousands of years after leaving Africa, to which evolution states that they will develop different from one another. But this is at most a few tens of thousands of years, probably not enough for extreme change.
Say in some dystopian world newborns wouldnt see their parents or any other people and be raised by a computer in the same way, then at the same age take an IQ test. The results would likely fit for all races.

But this difference being purely socioeconomic? Give me a break. Its a question of attitude amongst subcultures I think, when approaching the subject rationally. Speaking in very general and simplified terms of course so no SJW nonsense, the Asian community in the US was very much discriminated against in the old days. The difference is that after a few generations the Asians kicked their kids to school (often literally) while the Black community pretty much stayed put in the ghetto's. One subculture worked on pushing their way out of the low end of society, while the other did not. One now has high numbers of doctors and academics, the other does not. A matter of attitude and personal motivation. Asian people aren't less not-white than black or hispanic people are in the eyes of 18th century whites.

But it'll likely never be resolved because such racial studies are stricktly taboo so that the only 'research' outcomes will be short-sighted and biased SJW nonsense that is poorly researched and manipulates contrasting data, or racist blog posts that are even less researched and just look at simple data with way too many variables in it. A shame, because from a scientific point of view this would be rather interesting if we could only interpret this as purely an evolutionary study without any effect on our daily lives. But the social rammifications and fragmentation would be too severe of course.

Anyway thats how I see it. If you want to reply, please do but no emotional SJW crap. I'd be happy to have a proper rational discussion because I might well be wrong. And no "you Americans should" blabla, I'm not from the US.

There seems to be a lot of sample and survey theory behind it. For example, a survey about revenues can be done in many different ways, all mathematically correct. A completely random sample for example. There's a chance that you selected a billionaire with huge assets, and your average will explode, you'll say the average revenue in America is 2 million dollars a month. Is it invalid though ? The method isn't incorrect. What you can also do is ask people about their status in society. If a participant is a billionaire, take the proportion of billionaires and weigh their answer accordingly. You will get a much "better" average, still with an equally valid method.
You can also divide by state (stratified survey) and in each state you do the same as above. Is it even better ? It's more accurate. More mathematically valid ? No, just the same.
That's why statistics are a great defense, you can always say that you were just unlucky or that your method was mathematically solid, and it will be true. Texas Vs Wisconsin looks juste like that : you're not the best anywhere at school, you're always 2nd or third. So if we look at your results separately, you're just not the best. But every single time, the best in each subject is 4th or 5th in every other. So you're generally better than the subjects' valedictorians, and your global average makes you take the first place. So you're globally better than them and you're the actual valedictorian. Stats truly are an amazing thing.

If we correct the sample size and scale correctly, we get 4 dead humans with no treatment and 4 healthy cats with treatment. A biological application of this idea is in life history theory, which studies how different organisms evolve to allocate their resources differently. For example, it stands to reason that genotypes that make for many offspring can't make for particularly large offspring, or that individuals that invest a lot of resources in reproduction won't be able to invest as much in growing fast.

But in fact we often find positive correlations between traits, where some individuals e.g. have many large offspring and some have few, small offspring. When this happens, it means there's more variation in the absolute amounts of resources available to the organisms than there is variation in how they allocate the resources they have. (We see the same thing in human society, where people with large houses often also have fancy cars - because these individuals have more resources overall.) To see the life history trade-offs appear, we need to bring organisms into the lab and rear them under controlled conditions, where each genotype has the same amount of resources to work with.

In my experience the Simpson's Paradox often arrives because of the human incorrectly aggregating data, not an actual paradox. For example in the first proposed situation you cannot treat every tick or cross as equal even though each one represented one person/cat. (As the video wrongly has)

Instead you need to consider every 'box' equal instead. So if a box has more ticks or crosses than each tick and cross in that box needs to be made worth less.

In this instance you would make the ticks and crosses in the boxes with 4 each worth 0.25 while the single cross and tick would be worth one. Doing this removes the paradox and delivers a consistent interpreation regardless of how you compare the data

I like how you failed to follow your own advice when researching for this video. Being white doesn't make you socio-economically advantaged, and being black or hispanic doesn't make you disadvantaged. Socio-economic status is not derived from skin color or ethnicity. The #1 correlation for socio-economic advantage in students (both in Wisconsin and Texas) is children who are raised in a home with both their mother AND their father. If you correct for that, the socio-economic status of blacks, whites, hispanics, asians, etc., all end up the same.

The underlying cause of the Wisconsin-Texas thing is not that there are more "advantaged" students in one state, and disadvantaged students in another state. It's that in Texas, you have to teach material to students from all kinds of different cultures, opinions, and backgrounds, whereas in Wisconsin, the culture is pretty much homogeneous. When everybody is pretty much the same, and all come from the same background, it's easier to find teaching methods that make sense to everybody. In Wisconsin, you don't have to worry about tons of Hispanic students who grew up in a house that didn't speak English, and therefore has a harder time with tests written in English.

This is the same reason why nations like Japan have high test scores and seem to have great education systems: because everybody is exactly the same. There's no diversity of thought, opinion, culture, or background.

This was written about and studied extensively in the 1990s, but it was widely ignored because it seemed to imply that racial purity increased test scores (which it does). But because that's not politically correct, it was ignored. Funny how people who try to be politically correct often ignore data that doesn't fit the story that they're trying to propagandize, isn't it...

So much sense in aggregating the data when every population has a different number. In the second case (the wrong one) you're giving much more weight to the untreated cats rather than the untreated humans, and giving much more weight to the treated humans compared to treated cats. Since both the populations you give more weight to were the ones with more negative data, you end up with a false conclusion. It's not a paradox, it's understanding statistics
